stall torch==2.1.2+cpu -f https://download.pytorch.org/whl/torch_stable.html
If you're offline, let me know â€” Iâ€™ll help you install from a wheel instead.

ðŸ” Verify after reinstalling
Then run:

python3 -c "import torch; print(torch.__version__)"
If it prints 2.1.2, you're good.

Then:

python3 -c "from transformers import pipeline; print(pipeline('summarization', model='t5-small'))"
This should download the t5-small model once, then it will work fully offline.

âš¡ Bonus Tip (fully offline option)
If you're going to stay offline:

Download t5-small on another machine using:

from transformers import pipeline
pipeline("summarization", model="t5-small")
Copy the ~/.cache/huggingface folder onto your Chromebookâ€™s USB path at the same location

Set this env variable before running:

export TRANSFORMERS_CACHE="/mnt/chromeos/removable/USB Drive/.cache/huggingface"
Let me know:

Are you online and okay to reinstall PyTorch via pip?

Or fully offline and want an offline wheel/install approach?

I'll guide you accordingly.

You said:
(review_assistant_env) km_project@penguin:~$ python3 -c "import torch; print(torch.__version__)"

A module that was compiled using NumPy 1.x cannot be run in
NumPy 2.2.6 as it may crash. To support both 1.x and 2.x
versions of NumPy, modules must be compiled with NumPy 2.0.
Some module may need to rebuild instead e.g. with 'pybind11>=2.12'.

If you are a user of the module, the easiest solution will be to
downgrade to 'numpy<2' or try to upgrade the affected module.
We expect that some modules will need time to support NumPy 2.
